channel.title: KenSmith tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from KenSmith.

item.description: Outlining, a third try at thinking clearly about process, product, and #toolsforthought, growing out of a thread with @ReasonedWriting and @DaveWiner. https://t.co/cN833xnmjR
When writing is going well, organization both precedes and follows content. That's why a person might want to compose right there in the outline. #toolsforthought

If you write about the same thing three days in a row, 1) the focus will likely tighten, 2) the grain of the thinking grow finer, and 3) the organization evolve. I now think that those three things are the same thing, three ways of noticing and naming the process of writing.

@AndySylvester99 I like the principle, the practice, for sure. It reminds me of a collaboration many years ago between dozens of American poets, who all wrote a poem that included the presence of a woman in a black raincoat. It ended up as a book. (Maybe it was red.)

What is an outline? More than one thing . . . https://t.co/PI2HgV4g52
Expanding on a #toolsforthought thread from earlier in the day, where there were several contributions from @ReasonedWriting and @DaveWiner.
I got to learn a good bit about the proper placement of fridges and other support equipment in different kinds of medical facilities over lunch today. https://t.co/r56J6h05QM
https://t.co/gENZpwqUQN
@toebean_peets Decided to delete “near”…
Ode on a Tracking Number In the near future there'll be a present, but that future's sweet present likely soon will pass.
A Fortune Cookie https://t.co/Ys41StUdnk

I spoke in a university class yesterday. One question asked: If we want to have a protest in front of the courthouse tomorrow, would Twitter be the organizing tool to use? My answer: Probably, no, but maybe, it depends on what kind of web you have in place as a writer.
If one's online publishing is mainly a monologue, then it's not going to work.
If you've built a web of readers and writers who engage with each other around a topic, then tapping into that might work.
Gotta use the keyboard often to make things happen away from the keyboard.
@davewiner . . . and all the words were whispered from a Venn diagram, from the intersection of three circles labeled Surrealism, Hollywood, and What the Techsters Have Planned for Us.
Seems like this should be called “Backed into a Corner” but what’s the story? https://t.co/VdKwWhuLpG

@SusanDebraBlum It’s a writing tool where you compose right in the layered outline structure that you establish, flesh out, and revise as you write. The thinking and the outline grow in place together.
@SusanDebraBlum That sounds like the way I use the Drummer software.

Language always falls short. We do better when we remember that. “It is not on any map. True places never are.” —Herman Melville https://t.co/TUyzAw3R08 via Paul @Holdengraber https://t.co/qRkseehwip
A semi-circle of rusting Ford tractors on the edge of a one-church town.
"It is not on any map. True places never are."
Still pondering that Melville quotation yesterday from Paul @Holdengraber. https://t.co/XBbdkHpHC6

@liamputt If the whole nation ends up in the landfill beside our old white washers and dryers, we probably shouldn’t be surprised.
@liamputt If there’s anyone left to operate the landfill . . .

Schools used to teach outlining as a way to plan a piece of writing. I tend to use an outline as the actual place where I do the writing, thinking, and revising.
Not so much for poems, though.

Out by the curb, a city truck with its claw arm just grabbed the washing machine that served this household well since 1994. At the appliance shop, they shook their heads, saying, yes, they used to make them like that. Machines today, they said, are built to last 6-8 years.
How good writing resembles the two-tray balance from old chemistry labs. https://t.co/lCAgOuDSrz
Most social media platforms are pro-talker, anti-writer. https://t.co/TtNT1VKAPa
Not having to know. How this idea has evolved over a few years in this writer's social media posts. https://t.co/TtNT1VKAPa
Writers believe that similar versions of a sentence do not give the same pleasure nor mean the same thing.
Who else but Monty Python could make comedy from a two-tray balance we oldsters recall from chemistry lab days? https://t.co/0Yct3a9g2O https://t.co/HFhLBrVGYt
